docs.lead_paragraph: American Healthways said that it had agreed to acquire StatusOne Health Systems, a closely held provider of health management services, for $65 million. StatusOne, based in Westboro, Mass., provides health management services to high-risk health plan customers. American Healthways, based in Nashville, provides diabetes treatment programs and other services for health plans and hospitals.

headline.main: AMERICAN HEALTHWAYS TO BUY STATUSONE FOR $65 MILLION

docs.abstract: American Healthways acquires StatusOne Health Systems, closely held provider of health management services, for $65 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With an endorsement possibly imminent, most of the Democratic hopefuls for president lobbied the nation's fastest growing union for support today, though Howard Dean, Richard A. Gephardt and John Kerry appeared to have an edge. Eight of the nine candidates spoke at a convention here of the Service Employees International Union, which, with 1.5 million members, is the largest in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

headline.main: Presidential Hopefuls Courting Huge Union for Endorsement

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential hopefuls appear at Service Employees International Union convention, seeking endorsement from 1.5-million member body; union president Andrew L Stern says most popular candidates with members appear to be Dr Howard Dean, Rep Richard A Gephardt and Sen John Kerry; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With an endorsement possibly imminent, most of the Democratic hopefuls for president lobbied the nation's fastest growing union for support today, though Howard Dean, Richard A. Gephardt and John Kerry appeared to have an edge.    Eight of the nine...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some days around midmorning, if it's not too hot, too humid, too wet or too windy, the front doors of two houses on the same side of 103rd Street in Ozone Park open and two people in their 70's head down the block and across 101st Avenue to St. Mary Gate of Heaven Roman Catholic Church. One of them, Francis X. Forte, a vigorous Navy veteran of 77, marches quickly to the last table at the Ozone Park Senior Center, in the basement of the Queens church. There, with a bunch of old friends, he plays rumino -- an intense kind of knock rummy -- for $3 a hand until the center serves lunch.

headline.main: Some Feel Pinch, Others a Squeeze; In Tight Times, Elderly Neighbors Travel Different Paths

docs.abstract: Elderly are focus of article in Hard Times series on impact of New York's fiscal crisis on people who live, work and spend time in single city block in Ozone Park, Queens; some people, protected by generous company pension and tax exemptions, are feeling no pain, while others are struggling, just scraping by; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The exodus of health maintenance organizations from Medicare, a trend that has alarmed elderly people and members of Congress since 1999, will slow to a trickle next year, the industry said today. Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, the lobby for H.M.O.'s and other private plans, said they would drop 39,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year.

headline.main: Fewer People On Medicare Are Dropped By H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: American Assn of Health Plans says exodus of health maintenance organizations from Medicare, trend that has alarmed elderly and members of Congress, will slow to trickle; says HMO's and other private plans expect to drop 39,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year, as compared to 2.4 million dropped from 1999 to 2003 (M)
docs.snippet: The exodus of health maintenance organizations from Medicare, a trend that has alarmed elderly people and members of Congress since 1999, will slow to a trickle next year, the industry said today.    Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lucent Technologies, the telephone-equipment maker, said it was changing the health benefits of retirees to save $75 million a year. Lucent said it would stop reimbursing management retirees and their dependents for the cost of some Medicare premiums in 2004. The company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., will no longer pay for dental coverage of those retirees, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lucent cited in part a decline in the value of pension-plan assets, which had been used to help finance retiree health-care expenses. Those expenses will amount to $850 million this year, Lucent said. The company expects to pay as much as $350 million toward health costs for retired managers next year.

headline.main: TO CUT COSTS, LUCENT CHANGES BENEFITS FOR RETIREES

docs.abstract: Lucent Technologies is changing health benefits of retirees to save $75 million each year (S)
docs.snippet: Lucent Technologies, the telephone-equipment maker, said it was changing the health benefits of retirees to save $75 million a year. Lucent said it would stop reimbursing management retirees and their dependents for the cost of some Medicare premiums...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a third of the emergency grant money intended to help small businesses in Lower Manhattan survive after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack went to investment firms, financial traders and lawyers, a result that some New York legislators who helped secure money for the program say they never envisioned. Twenty-seven percent, or $144 million, of the $539 million World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant program went to traders who work on the floors of the financial district's stock and commodities exchanges, to brokerage firms and to investment banks, according to an analysis by The New York Times. An additional $53 million, or 10 percent of the total, went to law firms, some of which employ hundreds of attorneys and generate yearly revenues of tens of millions of dollars, and few of which faced dire threats to their survival.

headline.main: Downtown Grants Found To Favor Investment Field

docs.abstract: More than third of $539 million in emergency grant money intended to help small businesses in Lower Manhattan survive after Sept 11 terrorist attack went instead to investment firms, financial traders and lawyers; total of $197 million went to traders and lawyers, while far smaller amounts went to restaurants, retailers and other small businesses; inconsistencies in grant program are outcome of regulations drafted quickly by New York State officials, based on laws that were hastily written in Washington, all in effort to quickly distribute badly needed money to suffering businesses; legislation did not define small business; as result, any company with fewer than 500 employees was eligible for grants, with no restrictions as to annual revenues; detailed examination of recovery grant program and listing of who got how much; photo; chart; map (L)
docs.snippet: More than a third of the emergency grant money intended to help small businesses in Lower Manhattan survive after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack went to investment firms, financial traders and lawyers, a result that some New York legislators who...
